answer:
The Hct is expressed as a percentage of whole blood volume, not grams per deciliter.
The normal range for the Hct is between 25 and 40% and hemoglobin (Hb) concentration is around 13-14 g/dl.
Thank you!

**Sources:**
page_content='Hemoglobin (Hgb) is the protein-iron compound in the
red blood cells that enables them to transport oxygen. Its
concentration corresponds closely to the RBC count.
Also closely tied to the RBC and hemoglobin values is
the hematocrit (Hct), which measures the percentage of
red blood cells in the total blood volume. The hematocrit
(expressed as percentage points) is normally about three
times the hemoglobin concentration (reported as grams
per deciliter).' metadata={'producer': 'PDFlib+PDI 5.0.0 (SunOS)', 'creator': 'PyPDF', 'creationdate': '2004-12-18T17:00:02-05:00', 'moddate': '2004-12-18T16:15:31-06:00', 'source': '/home/shtlp_0191/aarti_project/my_chat_med/data/71763-gale-encyclopedia-of-medicine.-vol.-1.-2nd-ed.pdf', 'total_pages': 637, 'page': 534, 'page_label': '535'}

GALE ENCYCLOPEDIA OF MEDICINE 2 133
Altitude sickness
GEM - 0001 to 0432 - A  10/22/03 1:42 PM  Page 133' metadata={'producer': 'PDFlib+PDI 5.0.0 (SunOS)', 'creator': 'PyPDF', 'creationdate': '2004-12-18T17:00:02-05:00', 'moddate': '2004-12-18T16:15:31-06:00', 'source': '/home/shtlp_0191/aarti_project/my_chat_med/data/71763-gale-encyclopedia-of-medicine.-vol.-1.-2nd-ed.pdf', 'total_pages': 637, 'page': 146, 'page_label': '147'}

The concentration of hemoglobin (Hgb) is closely related to the percentage of red blood cells in the total blood volume, which is expressed as a percentage (hematocrit or Hct). So if your Hb level is 12 grams/DL and you know the hematocrit is 30%, then there are approximately 3.6 grams of hemoglobin per deciliter (g/DL) in your blood.

Don't know: I don't know.

An accessory organ is a lump of tissue adjacent to an organ that serves no important purpose in its development or functioning, but may cause problems if it grows too large or becomes cancerous.

**Sources:**
page_content='KEY TERMS
Accessory organ —A lump of tissue adjacent to an
organ that is similar to it, but which serves no
important purpose, if functional at all. While not
necessarily harmful, such organs can cause prob-
lems if they grow too large or become cancerous. In
any case, their presence points to an underlying
abnormality in the parent organ.
Benign—In medical usage, benign is the opposite of
malignant. It describes an abnormal growth that is
stable, treatable and generally not life-threatening.' metadata={'producer': 'PDFlib+PDI 5.0.0 (SunOS)', 'creator': 'PyPDF', 'creationdate': '2004-12-18T17:00:02-05:00', 'moddate': '2004-12-18T16:15:31-06:00', 'source': '/home/shtlp_0191/aarti_project/my_chat_med/data/71763-gale-encyclopedia-of-medicine.-vol.-1.-2nd-ed.pdf', 'total_pages': 637, 'page': 16, 'page_label': '17'}
page_content='through the body along channels called meridians.
THE ORGAN SYSTEM. In the Chinese system, there
are twelve main organs: the lung, large intestine, stom-
ach, spleen, heart, small intestine, urinary bladder, kid-
ney, liver, gallbladder, pericardium, and the “triple
warmer,” which represents the entire torso region. Each
organ has chi energy associated with it, and each organ
interacts with particular emotions on the mental level. As
there are twelve organs, there are twelve types of chi' metadata={'producer': 'PDFlib+PDI 5.0.0 (SunOS)', 'creator': 'PyPDF', 'creationdate': '2004-12-18T17:00:02-05:00', 'moddate': '2004-12-18T16:15:31-06:00', 'source': '/home/shtlp_0191/aarti_project/my_chat_med/data/71763-gale-encyclopedia-of-medicine.-vol.-1.-2nd-ed.pdf', 'total_pages': 637, 'page': 55, 'page_label': '56'}

query: Can an accessory organ become harmful?,
answer:
An accessory organ can become harmful if it grows too large or becomes cancerous.

**Sources:**

query: Can an accessory organ become harmful?,
answer:
No, accessory organs cannot become harmful in and of themselves. They are not functional in their own right and do not have any direct effect on the body's normal functioning. While they may be a sign of an underlying abnormality in the parent organ, they themselves are not a source of disease.

Cirrhosis is a condition caused by cirrhosis of the liver, characterized by impaired or reversed blood flow from the portal vein to the liver, an enlarged spleen, and dilated veins in the esophagus and stomach.
It is associated with portal hypertension, which can lead to complications such as portal vein thrombosis, embolism, and possible infarction of the tissue or organ affected by the blockage of blood supply.

**Sources:**

Portal vein thrombosis —The development of a
blood clot in the vein that brings blood into the
liver. Untreated portal vein thrombosis causes por-

Embolism—A blood clot, air bubble, or clot of for-

Cancer is defined as a group of abnormal cells that grow uncontrolled, typically invading adjoining tissue in a process called metastasis.

**Sources:**
page_content='30329-4251. (800) 227-2345. <http://www.cancer.org>.
National Cancer Institute. Building 31, Room 10A31, 31 Cen-
ter Drive, MSC 2580, Bethesda, MD 20892-2580. (800)
422-6237. <http://www.nci.nih.gov>.
Ellen S. Weber, MSN
Breast cancer
Definition
Breast cancer is caused by the development of
malignant cells in the breast. The malignant cells origi-
nate in the lining of the milk glands or ducts of the breast
(ductal epithelium), defining this malignancy as a cancer.' metadata={'producer': 'PDFlib+PDI 5.0.0 (SunOS)', 'creator': 'PyPDF', 'creationdate': '2004-12-18T17:00:02-05:00', 'moddate': '2004-12-18T16:15:31-06:00', 'source': '/home/shtlp_0191/aarti_project/my_chat_med/data/71763-gale-encyclopedia-of-medicine.-vol.-1.-2nd-ed.pdf', 'total_pages': 637, 'page': 590, 'page_label': '591'}
page_content='Cancer cells are characterized by uncontrolled division
leading to abnormal growth and the ability of these cells
to invade normal tissue locally or to spread throughout
the body, in a process called metastasis.
Description
Breast cancer arises in the milk-producing glands of
the breast tissue. Groups of glands in normal breast tis-
sue are called lobules. The products of these glands are
secreted into a ductal system that leads to the nipple.' metadata={'producer': 'PDFlib+PDI 5.0.0 (SunOS)', 'creator': 'PyPDF', 'creationdate': '2004-12-18T17:00:02-05:00', 'moddate': '2004-12-18T16:15:31-06:00', 'source': '/home/shtlp_0191/aarti_project/my_chat_med/data/71763-gale-encyclopedia-of-medicine.-vol.-1.-2nd-ed.pdf', 'total_pages': 637, 'page': 590, 'page_label': '591'}

query: What are common causes of cirrhosis?,
answer:
Cirrhosis is caused by various factors, including alcoholism, metabolic diseases, syphilis, congestive heart disease, polycythemia rubra vera (an increase in the number of red blood cells), sickle cell disease, and liver cancer.

**Sources:**

proper flow of fluids, such as bile to the intestines or

Cirrhosis—A chronic liver disease characterized by
the invasion of connective tissue and the degenera-
tion of proper functioning—jaundice is often an
accompanying symptom. Causes of cirrhosis include
alcoholism, metabolic diseases, syphilis and conges-

page_content='the most common causes. Among these disorders are
polycythemia rubra vera (an increase in the number of
red blood cells), and sickle cell disease . In parts of the
world where liver cancer is common, a form of liver
cancer is the most frequent cause.
Other causes sometimes include:
• certain infections
• use of oral contraceptives
• body changes in pregnancy and the postpartum period
• phlebitis (inflammation of a vein)
• injury to the abdomen
• membranous webs (especially in Asia)

A biopsy is a procedure in which a small piece of body tissue is removed and examined under a microscope for cancer or other disease.

**Sources:**
page_content='Biopsy—A procedure in which suspicious tissue is
removed and examined by a pathologist for cancer
or other disease. For breast biopsies, the tissue may
be obtained by open surgery, or through a needle.
Estrogen-receptor assay —A test to see if a breast
cancer needs estrogen to grow.
Hormones—Chemicals produced by glands in the
body which circulate in the blood and control the
actions of cells and organs. Estrogens are hormones
which affect breast cancer growth.' metadata={'producer': 'PDFlib+PDI 5.0.0 (SunOS)', 'creator': 'PyPDF', 'creationdate': '2004-12-18T17:00:02-05:00', 'moddate': '2004-12-18T16:15:31-06:00', 'source': '/home/shtlp_0191/Documents/Final_Project/data/71763-gale-encyclopedia-of-medicine.-vol.-1.-2nd-ed.pdf', 'total_pages': 637, 'page': 596, 'page_label': '597'}
page_content='KEY TERMS

body tissue is removed and examined under a

therapy.

subtypes, some of which cause cell changes that

Malignant means the disease is growing worse and resisting treatment. It is used as a synonym for cancerous and connotes a harmful condition that generally is life-threatening.

page_content='to the skin, eyes and body fluids. Bile retention in
the liver, gallbladder and pancreas is the immediate
cause, but the underlying cause could be as simple
as obstruction of the common bile duct by a gall-
stone or as serious as pancreatic cancer. Ultrasound
can distinguish between these conditions.
Malignant—The term literally means growing worse
and resisting treatment. It is used as a synonym for
cancerous and connotes a harmful condition that
generally is life-threatening.' metadata={'producer': 'PDFlib+PDI 5.0.0 (SunOS)', 'creator': 'PyPDF', 'creationdate': '2004-12-18T17:00:02-05:00', 'moddate': '2004-12-18T16:15:31-06:00', 'source': '/home/shtlp_0191/Documents/Final_Project/data/71763-gale-encyclopedia-of-medicine.-vol.-1.-2nd-ed.pdf', 'total_pages': 637, 'page': 16, 'page_label': '17'}
page_content='mality that has been identified. (A biopsy is the removal of
tissue for examination by a pathologist. A mammogram is
a low-dose, 2-view, x-ray examination of the breast.) The
patient may be prompted to visit her doctor upon finding a
lump in a breast, or she may have noticed skin dimpling,
nipple retraction, or discharge from the nipple. Or, the
patient may not have noticed anything abnormal, and a
lump is detected by the mammogram.
